item.title: Middle East Crisis: As Israel Fights Again in Gaza’s North, Military’s Discontent Grows
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Putin Will Visit Xi, Testing a ‘No Limits’ Partnership
item.description: Moscow seeks more support for its war in Ukraine. But Beijing risks alienating Europe, a key trading partner needed to help revive China’s economy.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson and Paul Sonne
item.media:credit: Pavel Byrkin/Sputnik, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A photo provided by Russian state media showing President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and China’s leader, Xi Jinping, after talks at the Kremlin in Moscow last year.

item.title: Ukraine Needs Money to Fight. Can Seized Russian Assets Help?
item.description: Kyiv’s supporters are discussing how to use the interest earned by frozen Russian assets to help pay for weapons and postwar reconstruction.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: Repairing tanks and other vehicles in the Donetsk region of eastern Ukraine this month.

item.title: The Other Busing Program: Mexico Is Pushing Migrants Back South
item.description: In response to pressure from the Biden administration to curb migration flows, Mexico has quietly bused thousands of migrants away from the U.S. border to sites deep in the country’s south.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero, Paulina Villegas and Luis Antonio Rojas
item.media:credit: Luis Antonio Rojas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Migrants listening to guidelines from a staff member at the Oasis De Paz Del Espíritu Santo Amparito shelter in Villahermosa, Mexico.

item.title: Roman Polanski Did Not Defame British Actress, French Court Rules
item.description: Charlotte Lewis, who says the director raped her in the 1980s, brought the lawsuit against him over an interview in which he called the accusations an “odious lie.”
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: Roman Polanski in Paris in 2019.

item.title: How One Crack in the Line Opened a Path for the Russians
item.description: When Russian soldiers suddenly showed up in the small town of Ocheretyne in the east, it was clear that something had gone wrong.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Tyler Hicks
item.media:description: Paramedics with the 59th Separate Motorized Infantry Brigade of the Ukrainian army evacuating wounded soldiers from battles raging on the front line of the Donetsk region, this month.

item.title: Kenya Rallies Police Officers Ahead of Haiti Deployment
item.description: The East African country is preparing to send hundreds of police officers as the first wave of a multinational force aimed at stabilizing the chaos-ridden Caribbean nation.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:description: Kenyan anti-riot police officers on patrol last year on a highway that runs by an impoverished neighborhood.

item.title: Anti-Monarchy Activist in Thailand Dies After Hunger Strike
item.description: Netiporn Sanesangkhom, 28, supported abolishing the law that prohibits criticizing royalty and wanted to push the authorities to stop jailing political activists.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:description: Thailand’s Parliament. The governing party said last year that lawmakers would discuss changes to the law against criticism of the monarchy, but later backtracked.

item.title: Manhunt Underway in France After Prisoner Escapes in Ambush
item.description: The French authorities said that armed assailants had attacked a prison convoy, killed at least two prison officers and freed an inmate.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: France’s justice minister, Éric Dupond-Moretti, said that three other officers had been injured in the episode.

item.title: Iranian Film Director Mohammad Rasoulof Flees Country After Jail Sentence
item.description: Mohammad Rasoulof, known for the award-winning “There Is No Evil,” had been barred from leaving Iran after his work criticized Iran’s authoritarian rule.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: “I had to choose between prison and leaving Iran,” the director Mohammad Rasoulof said. “With a heavy heart, I chose exile.”

item.title: Georgia’s Parliament Gives Final Approval to ‘Foreign Agents’ Measure
item.description: The president has vowed to veto the legislation, which critics say could push the country back into Russia’s orbit. The governing party says it can override a veto.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: A march to protest the controversial bill in Tbilisi, Georgia, on Monday.

item.title: European Union 2024 Election: What to Know
item.description: Voters in all the 27 countries that make up the European Union are heading to polls in June to choose their representatives in the European Parliament.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Monika Pronczuk
item.media:description: A giant poster announcing the upcoming European elections was placed on the facade of the European Parliament building in Strasbourg, France.

item.title: Curfew Imposed in New Caledonia Following Protests Over Constitutional Change
item.description: The unrest was set off by a plan to let more French citizens vote in the territory, which independence activists say would water down their movement.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Smoke rising over New Caledonia’s capital, Noumea, on Tuesday as protests continued. The French authorities in the territory said they would mobilize security forces.

item.title: Mumbai Storm Topples Huge Billboard, Killing 14
item.description: Officials are investigating the collapse of the structure, which they said had been erected without permission.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.media:description: The billboard fell on a gas station in suburban Mumbai where people had taken shelter from a storm.

item.title: German Court Fines Far-Right Leader for Using Nazi Phrase
item.description: Björn Höcke, a state leader of the nationalist Alternative for Germany party, repeatedly used the phrase “Everything for Germany,” a slogan of the Nazi paramilitary wing, during campaign stops.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Björn Höcke at his trial in Halle, eastern Germany, on Tuesday. He claimed during the proceedings that he had not known about the phrase’s Nazi origin.

item.title: Russia Detains Senior General, Widening Military Purge
item.description: Lt. Gen. Yuri Kuznetsov became the second senior defense official to be detained on an accusation of corruption in the past month.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:credit: Russian Defense Ministry, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A photo made available by the Russian Defense Ministry of Lt. Gen. Yuri Kuznetsov.

item.title: U.N. Cites a Lower Death Toll Among Women and Children in Gaza
item.description: The overall count of those killed has not declined, but incomplete information about many of them has prompted the United Nations to use more conservative figures for children and women.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Lauren Leatherby and Abu Bakr Bashir
item.media:credit: Samar Abu Elouf for The New York Times
item.media:description: A woman mourning the loss of her siblings killed in Israeli airstrikes in the Gaza Strip in October.

item.title: Orcas Sink Another Boat Near Iberia, Worrying Sailors Before Summer
item.description: Two people were rescued on Sunday after orcas damaged their boat near the Strait of Gibraltar, where the animals have caused havoc in recent years.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai

item.title: Summer 2023 Was the Northern Hemisphere’s Hottest in 2,000 Years, Study Finds
item.description: Scientists used tree rings to compare last year’s extreme heat with temperatures over the past two millenniums.
item.dc:creator: Delger Erdenesanaa
item.media:description: A 730-year-old fir tree in Mount Rainier National Park, Wash. Researchers used data from 10,000 trees across the Northern Hemisphere.

item.title: Red Lobster Temporarily Closes Dozens of Restaurants
item.description: The seafood chain has been losing money for years. The liquidator behind the auction said more than 50 of its U.S. locations had closed.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.media:description: A Red Lobster restaurant in Rohnert Park, Calif., is one of the locations listed on an auction website as selling its equipment.

item.title: Alarmed by Climate Change, Astronomers Train Their Sights on Earth
item.description: A growing number of researchers in the field are using their expertise to fight the climate crisis.
item.dc:creator: Katrina Miller and Delger Erdenesanaa
item.media:credit: David Maurice Smith for The New York Times
item.media:description: Penny Sackett, former director of the Australian National University’s Mount Stromlo Observatory, just outside Canberra, in the remains of the observatory, which was destroyed in a 2003 wildfire.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Michael Cohen’s testimony.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Michael Cohen spoke about doing Donald Trump’s dirty work for a decade.

item.title: International UN Worker Is Killed in Gaza
item.description: It was the first time an international U.N. employee had been killed in Gaza since the war began last October.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi

item.title: Protesters Disrupt Israeli Memorial Day Events Over War Raging in Gaza
item.description: A day of national mourning was interrupted by hecklers who blamed government officials for failing to secure the release of hostages still being held by Hamas.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley, Myra Noveck, Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Thomas Fuller
item.media:description: Israel’s national security minister, Itamar Ben-Gvir, left, speaking at a Memorial Day ceremony in Ashdod, Israel, on Monday.

item.title: White House Says Israel Still Has Provided No Plan to Protect Rafah Civilians
item.description: The national security adviser, Jake Sullivan, also said Israel had yet to connect its military operations to a plan for the future governance of Gaza.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Zach Montague
item.media:description: Jake Sullivan, President Biden’s national security adviser, at the White House, on Monday.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing: The Prosecution’s Star Witness at the Trump Trial
item.description: Also, Vladimir Putin’s new defense minister.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Michael Cohen said that working for Donald Trump was the fulfillment of a youthful dream.

item.title: New Rules to Overhaul Electric Grids Could Boost Wind and Solar Power
item.description: The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission approved the biggest changes in more than a decade to the way U.S. power lines are planned and funded.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer
item.media:credit: Renaud Philippe for The New York Times
item.media:description: A transmission line construction project near Bingham, Maine, in 2022.

item.title: Finnish Lawmaker Who Fired Gun Outside Bar Is Expelled From Party
item.description: The lawmaker, Timo Vornanen, from the right-wing nationalist Finns Party is the latest party figure to come under scrutiny. He said he would continue in Parliament.
item.dc:creator: Johanna Lemola and Emma Bubola

item.title: Putin’s New Defense Minister Signals Russia’s Plan for a Long War in Ukraine
item.description: In his first public appearance as the newly appointed defense minister, Andrei R. Belousov spoke about veterans’ benefits and overcrowded hospitals rather than a new offensive in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:description: Andrei R. Belousov, the newly appointed defense minister, at a hearing on Monday in the Russian Parliament, in a photo made available by the Russian Federation Council.

item.title: As Russia Advances on Kharkiv, Ukraine Faces Shortages of Weapons and Troops
item.description: Ukraine’s forces are stretched thin and have minimal reserves to draw on, the chief of military intelligence said, in addition to shortages of weapons.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut, Maria Varenikova and Michael Schwirtz
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents from the village of Liptsi, in northeastern Ukraine, arriving at an evacuation point as they made their way to Kharkiv on Sunday.

item.title: U.K. Police Charge 3 Men With Aiding Hong Kong Intelligence Service
item.description: The three appeared in court on Monday after being arrested under Britain’s National Security Act. Eight other people detained in the case have been released.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: The three men charged appeared at Westminster Magistrates’ Court on Monday.

item.title: Chinese Woman Jailed for Reporting on Covid Set to be Freed
item.description: Yet Zhang Zhan’s supporters and human rights activists who had followed her case said they could not reach her or her family members.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: A pro-democracy activist holding a placard demanding the release of Zhang Zhan, outside the Chinese central government’s liaison office in Hong Kong in 2020.

item.title: Israelis Mark Memorial Day Among Portraits of Those Lost at the Nova Festival Ground
item.description: “Our hearts are broken,” one mourner said at the site of a rave for peace and love where hundreds were killed in the Hamas-led attack on Oct. 7.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: A woman sitting on Monday near portraits of the hundreds of people who came to the Nova music festival in southern Israel last October and never made it home.

item.title: Activists Hold Annual Israeli-Palestinian Memorial Day Ceremony
item.description: “Many people have woken up to the reality that this conflict cannot go on,” said a director of one Israeli peace-building group, referring to the decades of violence.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg

item.title: Minnesota and Wisconsin See Air Quality Warnings as Canadian Wildfire Smoke Drifts South
item.description: As smoke from wildfires drifted south over the weekend, officials urged people to avoid prolonged exertion and to limit their time outdoors.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:credit: Alberta Wildfire Service, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Smoke from wildfires burning east of Teepee Creek in Alberta, Canada, on Friday.

item.title: Secret Hamas Files Show It Spied on Everyday Palestinians
item.description: Hamas monitored political activity, online posts, and apparently even love lives. Palestinians were stuck between an Israeli blockade and a repressive security force.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon and Ronen Bergman
item.media:description: A rally in support of Hamas in Gaza City in 2022. A secret police force overseen by Hamas’s leader in the enclave utilizes an extensive network of informants.

item.title: Violent Unrest Over Economic Strife Erupts in Pakistan’s Kashmir Region
item.description: “I have never seen such a large-scale uprising” in the restive region, a teacher at a local university said.
item.dc:creator: Salman Masood
item.media:description: Police officers clashing with demonstrators in Muzaffarabad, Pakistan, on Saturday.

item.title: Cold Lava and Floods Kill 37 on Indonesian Island of Sumatra
item.description: Heavy rain on the island of Sumatra caused torrents of rock and ash to flow down a volcano and into nearby towns. At least 17 people were still missing.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang and Muktita Suhartono

item.title: Monday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Evacuees arriving in Kharkiv on Sunday.

item.title: A Night to Remember at the Opera, Complete With a Phantom
item.description: About 130 children took part in a sleepover at Rome’s opera house, part of a campaign to make up for a lack of music education by making the theater and the art form more familiar and accessible.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo and Alessandro Penso
item.media:credit: Alessandro Penso for The New York Times

item.title: Fighting Flares Anew in Gaza as Hamas Regroups
item.description: The U.S. secretary of state warned that Israel’s victories over Hamas may not be “sustainable.”
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack, Aaron Boxerman and Eric Nagourney
item.media:description: A missile hitting a building in northern Gaza, seen from Israel, on Saturday.

item.title: Spain’s Socialists Win Catalan Vote Dominated by Amnesty for Separatists
item.description: For the first time in over a decade, the regional government in Catalonia may be led by a party opposed to independence.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Chaundler
item.media:description: The Socialist leader in Catalonia, Salvador Illa, center, celebrating in Barcelona.

item.title: Monday Briefing: Russia Pushes Into Northern Ukraine
item.description: Also, fighting is raging in northern Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Olha Melnichuk, an 85-year-old Ukrainian, was evacuated to Kharkiv on Saturday.

item.title: Putin Replaces Defense Minister in Rare Cabinet Shake-up
item.description: Mr. Putin shifted Sergei Shoigu to run the security council, and nominated an economist to run the defense ministry.
item.dc:creator: Paul Sonne and Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sergei K. Shoigu at the Victory Day military parade in Moscow this month.

item.title: Blinken Says U.S. Has Not Ruled Out Withholding More Military Aid From Israel
item.description: The secretary of state said the U.S. could pull additional support if Israel undertakes a major attack on Rafah.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg and Minho Kim
item.media:description: Antony J. Blinken, the U.S. secretary of state, at the State Department on Friday.

item.title: Mystery of Mona Lisa’s Location May Be Solved
item.description: A mash-up of geology and art history has identified a likely setting for one of the world’s most famous paintings.
item.dc:creator: Ali Watkins
item.media:description: A geologist said the shape of the lake and the gray-white limestone in the background of Leonardo da Vinci’s Mona Lisa helped identify the setting of the portrait.

item.title: Russian Forces Push Deeper Into Northern Ukraine
item.description: With Ukrainian troops outnumbered, exhausted and now in retreat near Kharkiv, many Ukrainians wonder if the war has taken a significant turn for the worse.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman and Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Evacuees from the Ukrainian village of Lyptsi, near the Russian border, being taken to the city of Kharkiv on Sunday.

item.title: About 300,000 Gazans Have Fled Rafah, U.N. Says
item.description: The Israeli military has expanded its evacuation orders for Rafah, deepening fears that it was preparing a full-scale invasion of the city in southern Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.media:description: Palestinians seeking water at a tent camp in Deir al Balah, in the central Gaza Strip, on Saturday.

item.title: Can Parrots Converse? Polly Says That’s the Wrong Question.
item.description: In a cautious new paper, scientists tried to determine whether an interactive speech board might enrich the life of a parrot named Ellie.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes

item.title: Ukraine’s Seaborne Grain Exports Bounce Back to Near Prewar Levels
item.description: The flow of grain ships through ports in the Odesa region is a welcome boost for Ukraine’s war-ravaged economy. But analysts warn it may not last.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Oksana Parafeniuk for The New York Times
item.media:description: A 700-foot Liberian-flagged ship carrying corn bound for Bangladesh leaving the Ukrainian port of Odesa in March.

item.title: Elon Musk’s Diplomacy: Woo Right-Wing World Leaders. Then Benefit.
item.description: Mr. Musk has built a constellation of like-minded heads of state — including Argentina’s Javier Milei and India’s Narendra Modi — to push his own politics and expand his business empire.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Mac, Jack Nicas and Alex Travelli

item.title: Bus Crash in Indonesia Kills 11, Including Students, After Graduation Celebration
item.description: The vehicle was carrying dozens of teachers and students when it sped out of control on a downhill road and crashed into several vehicles in a hilly resort area.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young
item.media:description: Police officers and rescuers inspecting the wreckage of a bus after a crash on Saturday in Subang, Indonesia.

item.title: Yahya Sinwar Helped Start the War in Gaza. Now He’s Key to Its Endgame.
item.description: Hamas’s leader in Gaza is considered an architect of the Oct. 7 attacks that prompted Israel to retaliate. As mediators seek a cease-fire, a deal depends on Mr. Sinwar as well as his Israeli foes.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley, Julian E. Barnes and Adam Rasgon
item.media:description: Yahya Sinwar, center, Hamas’s leader in Gaza, in Gaza City last year. He is now believed to be hiding in a tunnel network in the enclave.

item.title: The Controversy Over K-pop Band NewJeans
item.description: The firm Hybe has lost hundreds of millions of dollars in market value because of a feud with the creative force behind the band NewJeans.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young
item.media:description: Min Hee-jin, who developed the band NewJeans and is embroiled in a dispute with her employer, at a news conference last month in Seoul.

item.title: Ahead of Olympics, World Anti-Doping Agency Faces a Trust Crisis
item.description: Concerns are growing that the body whose job is keeping sports free of illegal drugs is failing at that mission, leading Congress to question U.S. support.
item.dc:creator: Michael S. Schmidt, Jenny Vrentas and Tariq Panja
item.media:description: The World Anti-Doping Agency president, Witold Banka, has defended his organization’s handling of a doping case involving 23 Chinese swimmers.

item.title: As Israel Steps Up Attacks, 300,000 Gazans Are Forced to Evacuate
item.description: Many say there is nowhere to go, and even the “humanitarian zone” recommended by Israel is neither safe nor equipped to handle all of them, the U.N. says.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim, Bilal Shbair, Aaron Boxerman and Ben Shpigel
item.category: United Nations Relief and Works Agency
item.media:description: Fleeing Rafah, in southern Gaza, on Saturday. Around 150,000 have left Rafah in the past week, after the Israeli military ordered an evacuation.

item.title: Russian Attacks Open a New Front in Ukraine
item.description: Russia’s latest offensive has expanded the battlefield along Ukraine’s northern border, and sent thousands of civilians fleeing to Kharkiv, the closest large city.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman and Emile Ducke
item.media:description: Olha Melnichuk, an 85-year-old resident of Liptsi, near the Russian border, was evacuated to a shelter in Kharkiv, the country’s second-largest city, on Saturday.
